itns1019.content:
You can use keyboard shortcuts to quickly accomplish many tasks in iTunes. To find the shortcuts for common commands, look in the iTunes menus, or use the table below as a reference. Many items in iTunes (for example, songs and column headings) also have contextual menus. To see a contextual menu, press the Control key and click the item. To perform an action, press the shortcut keys indicated below.

Action

Shortcut

Playback shortcuts

 

Start or stop playing the selected song

Space bar

Play the currently selected song from the beginning

Return

Move forward or backward within a song

Command-Option-Arrow

Listen to the next or previous album in a list

Option-Right Arrow or Left Arrow

Go to the next or previous song in a list

Left Arrow or Right Arrow (or click the Skip Forward or Skip Backward controls in the upper-left corner of the iTunes window)

Library and playlist shortcuts

 

Select or deselect all the songs in a list

Command-click the checkbox next to a song

Create a playlist from a selection of songs

Shift-click the Add (+) button (or drag the songs to the white area of the source pane)

Create a new Smart Playlist

Option-click the Add (+) button

Reshuffle the current playlist

Option-click the Shuffle button

Delete the selected playlist from your source pane without confirming that you want to delete it

Command-Delete

Delete the selected playlist and all the songs it contains from your library

Option-Delete

Delete the selected song from your library and all playlists

Option-Delete

Refresh the Radio or iTunes DJ list (when selected, below Library)

Command-R

Refresh a Genius Playlist (when selected, below Genius)

Command-R

iTunes Store shortcuts

 

Go to the next page in the iTunes Store

Command-Right bracket ( ] )

Go to the previous page in the iTunes Store

Command-Left bracket ( [ )

Initiate a search in the iTunes Store (from anywhere in iTunes)

Type a word or phrase in the Search field and press Option-Return

Check for app updates (when Apps is selected, below Library)

Command-R

File and window shortcuts

 

Change the song information columns

Control-click a column heading

Expand or collapse all the triangles in the Radio’s Stream list

Command-click a triangle

Shrink the iTunes window to show only the playback controls

Click the zoom control in the upper-left corner of the iTunes window

Zoom the window to an ideal size

Option-click the zoom button in the upper-left corner of the iTunes window

See the iTunes window resize while you are resizing it

Command-drag the resize box in the lower-right corner of the window

In the Get Info window, see the info for the next or previous song in the list

Command-N or Command-P

Go to the previous or next pane in the Get Info or Preferences window

Shift-Command-Left Bracket ( [ ) or Shift-Command-Right Bracket ( ] )

Select the search field

Command-Option-F

See more options when a visual effect is showing

Press ?, then press the indicated key to use an option (not all visual effects support this)

Choose artwork for the selected video

While the video is playing, press the Control key, click the movie, and choose Set Poster Frame

iPod shortcuts

 

Prevent iPod from automatically syncing when you connect it to your computer

Press and hold Command-Option as you connect the iPod to your computer until the iPod appears in the iTunes window

iPhone shortcuts

 

Prevent iPhone from automatically syncing when you connect it to your computer

Press and hold Command-Option as you connect the iPhone to your computer until the iPhone appears in the iTunes window

Spoken word shortcuts

 

Go to the next or last chapter (if available)

Shift-Command-Right Arrow or Shift-Command-Left Arrow

iTunes menu shortcuts

 

Open iTunes Preferences

Command-Comma

Hide the iTunes window

Command-H

Hide all other applications

Option-Command-H

Quit iTunes

Command-Q

File menu shortcuts

 

Create a new playlist

Command-N

Create a new playlist with the selected songs

Shift-Command-N

Create a new Smart Playlist

Option-Command-N

Add a file to your music library

Command-O

Close the iTunes window

Command-W

Open the song or CD Info window for the selected song or CD

Command-I

Show where a song file is located

Shift-Command-R

Show the currently playing song in the list

Command-L

Edit menu shortcuts

 

Undo your last typing change while still in edit mode

Command-Z

Cut the selected song’s information or artwork

Command-X

Copy the selected song’s information or artwork

Command-C

Paste the selected song’s information or artwork

Command-V

Select all the songs in the list

Command-A

Deselect all the songs in the list

Shift-Command-A

Hide or show the Artist and Album columns

Command-B

Hide or show the song artwork

Command-G

Open the View Options window for the selected source

Command-J

Control menu shortcuts

 

Start or stop playing the selected song

Space Bar

When a song is playing, play the next song in a list

Right Arrow

When a song is playing, play the previous song in a list

Left Arrow

Increase the volume

Command-Up Arrow

Decrease the volume

Command-Down Arrow

Mute the sound (song keeps playing)

Option-Command-Down Arrow

Eject a CD

Command-E

Visualizer menu shortcuts

 

Turn the visualizer on or off

Command-T

Switch between visual effects using the entire screen or appearing in the iTunes window (when visualizer is on)

Command-F

Advanced menu shortcuts

 

Stream audio file at a specific URL to iTunes

Command-U

View menu shortcuts

 

Display video half size

Command-0

Display video actual size

Command-1

Display video double size

Command-2

Display video to fit screen

Command-3

Display video full screen

Control-Command-F

Exit full-screen view

Command-F

Window menu shortcuts

 

Put the iTunes window in the Dock

Command-M

Help menu shortcuts

 

Open iTunes Help

Command-?

General shortcuts

 

Open iTunes in “safe mode” (without external plug-ins)

Command-Option (while opening iTunes)

itns26856.content:
You can use Autofill to add songs to your iPod, iPhone, or iPad with a single click. You can set Autofill to select songs at random, or you can customize your settings.

You can select these options in the Autofill Settings window:

Other options are available at the bottom of the Music pane:

See also
Sync your device manually
itns26856.name: Autofill Settings
itns26856.summary: You can set your preferences for Autofill

itns26874.name: Download educational media from iTunes U

itns27548.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

Library Name

You can rename your iTunes library. This is useful if you use more than one library. If you turn on iTunes library sharing, others will see this name.

“Show” checkboxes

Display or hide items in the iTunes window.

Source Text

Change the text size for items listed on the left side of the iTunes window.

List Text

Change the text size for items in your library, when you use list view.

Grid View

Change the background for items in your library, when you use grid view.

When you insert a CD

Change what happens when you insert a CD in your computer’s CD drive.

Automatically retrieve CD track names from Internet

Automatically display song and artist names when you insert an audio CD. (To retrieve track names, you must be connected to the Internet.)

Check for new software updates automatically

Display a message when a new version of iTunes is available.

See also
Use multiple iTunes libraries
Keyboard shortcuts
Customize the iTunes window
If you don’t see song information
Accessibility solutions for iTunes
itns27548.name: iTunes General preferences
itns27548.summary: How to use the iTunes General preferences pane

itns27551.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

Crossfade Songs

Fade songs in and out, with no silence between songs. Drag the slider to change the amount of time it takes for the current song to fade out at the end and the new song to fade in.

Sound Enhancer

Change the music’s sound quality during playback. Drag the slider to increase or decrease the Sound Enhancer’s effect.

Sound Check

Play all music and video at the same volume level.

Play Movies and TV Shows

Play movies and TV shows in artwork viewer, a different part of the iTunes window, full screen, or in a separate window. If the visualizer is on and “Full screen with visuals” is selected, video in a playlist plays audio only.

Play Music Videos

Play music videos in artwork viewer, a different part of the iTunes window, full screen, or in a separate window. If the visualizer is on and “Full screen with visuals” is selected, video in a playlist plays audio only.

Audio Language

Change the default playback language.

Subtitle Language

Change the language used for movie subtitles and closed captions.

Play videos using standard definition version

Always play non-HD video, even if a high-definition version is available. You might want to choose this if you have an older computer that can’t play HD video well.

Show closed captioning when available

Display a text transcript of dialog and voiceover while playing movies and TV shows.

See also
Play, shuffle, or repeat songs
Adjust the sound quality
Turn on visual effects
Use subtitles and alternative audio tracks
itns27551.name: iTunes Playback preferences
itns27551.summary: How to use the iTunes Playback preferences pane

itns27552.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

Look for shared libraries

Display music and video being shared by others on your local network (using Wi-Fi or a cable connection).

Shared libraries and playlists appear in the left side of the iTunes window below Shared.

Share my library on my local network

Allow up to five other computers on your local network to display and play items from your library. You can share your entire library or select specific playlists to share.

If you select “Require password,” others can see your library but they can’t play anything without the password you specify.

See also
Share your iTunes library
itns27552.name: iTunes Sharing preferences
itns27552.summary: How to use the iTunes Sharing preferences pane

itns27553.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

iTunes Media folder location

To change where songs and other files you import into iTunes are located, click Change.

To change back to the original location for files (Home/Music/iTunes), click Reset.

Keep iTunes Media folder organized

Automatically put imported music into folders for album and artist.

Copy files to iTunes Media folder when adding to library

Copy an item to the iTunes Media folder when you drag the item to the iTunes window or choose File > “Add to Library.”

If you want items to appear in iTunes but also remain in their original location, deselect this checkbox. For example, you can keep music imported from CDs on your computer’s hard disc, and save your video files on an external hard disc.

Pressing the Option key while dragging temporarily reverses the current checkbox setting.

Streaming Buffer Size

Change how much audio or video is downloaded before it starts to play. A larger buffer can help video play more smoothly. If you have a fast Internet connection, a smaller buffer can help the movie start playing more quickly.

Use iTunes for Internet playback

Use iTunes to play Internet radio stations, MP3s, and other audio files on the Internet.

Reset all dialog warnings

If you selected “Do not show this message again” in one or more dialogs (small windows with messages in them), clicking Reset makes the messages appear again, as if you’d just opened iTunes for the first time.

Reset iTunes Store cache

iTunes saves the store pages you visit on your computer in a temporary location called the “cache.” If you return later, iTunes can retrieve the page from the cache faster than getting it from the Internet.

If the content on a page seems outdated, you may want to reset the cache to make iTunes retrieve the latest version of the page. If you think a page is not opening properly, resetting the cache may help.

Keep Mini Player on top of all other windows

Keep the Mini Player (the iTunes window after you click the green zoom button) in front of all open windows, even while you use applications other than iTunes.

Keep movie window on top of all other windows

When playing video in a separate window, keep the movie window in front of all open windows, even while you use applications other than iTunes.

Display visualizer full screen

Show visual effects full screen instead of within the iTunes window.

See also
iTunes Store overview
Find iTunes files
Add items to your library without copying them to your iTunes folder
Listen to Internet radio
Customize the iTunes window
Turn on visual effects
itns27553.name: iTunes Advanced preferences
itns27553.summary: How to use the iTunes Advanced preferences pane

itns27555.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

Automatically check for available downloads

iTunes displays the number of items you previously purchased from the iTunes Store but didn’t download.

Automatically download pre-purchased content

Automatically download items you pay for in advance, such as new episodes of a TV show you purchased with a Season Pass, as they become available. If multiple computers are authorized for your iTunes Store account, you can only set up one for automatic downloads.

Automatically download missing album artwork

Automatically add album artwork for music you import into iTunes from CDs or other sources. Artwork is already included with all music purchased from the iTunes Store.

Use full window for iTunes Store

Selecting this preference hides the lists on the left side of the iTunes window (Library, Store, and so on) when you enter the iTunes Store. To exit the iTunes Store when the lists are hidden, click the “X” at the upper left of the store window or press the Escape key on your keyboard.

If you use a screen reader, the lists can’t be hidden, even if you select this option.

See also
iTunes Store overview
Buy items from the iTunes Store
Verify iTunes Store purchases
Set up an Apple ID account for use in the iTunes Store
Pre-order items from the iTunes Store
itns27555.name: iTunes Store preferences
itns27555.summary: How to use the iTunes Store preferences pane

itns27559.content:
iTunes lets you restrict or prevent access to the iTunes Store, shared libraries, and certain types of content. For computers with multiple user accounts, you can set different controls for specific users, but still allow unrestricted access from administrator accounts.

Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

“Disable” checkboxes

Prevent access to certain parts of iTunes. To prevent access to the iTunes Store, but still allow access to educational content, select both “iTunes Store” and “Allow access to iTunes U.”

“Ratings for” menu

Choose the rating system for the country you’re in.

Show content ratings in library

Display or hide Explicit ratings for items in your iTunes library.

Content Restrictions

Restrict access to items in the iTunes Store by ratings and type of content. Password is required for previews and purchases of restricted items.

Click the lock to prevent further changes

Prevent unwanted changes to parental controls by requiring an administrator’s password to unlock.

See also
Restrict access to explicit content in the iTunes Store
About parental advisory labels
itns27559.name: iTunes Parental Control preferences
itns27559.summary: How to use the Parental preferences pane

itns27561.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

Apple TVs connected to iTunes

Displays a list of Apple TVs that are set up to play content from this computer.

Prevent Apple TVs from syncing automatically

Prevents Apple TVs from syncing automatically when connected to this iTunes library. When you select this checkbox, connected Apple TVs can only be synced manually.

Remove Apple TV

Disconnect the selected Apple TV from this computer.

See also
Play items in your iTunes library using Apple TV (1st generation)
Play items in your iTunes library using Apple TV (1st generation)
itns27561.name: iTunes Apple TV preferences
itns27561.summary: How to use the Apple TV preferences pane

itns27563.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

Device backups

Displays a list of backups of devices that are synced with this computer. Encrypted backups are identified with a lock icon. Position the pointer over an item on the list to display the device’s serial number.

Prevent iPods, iPhones, and iPads from syncing automatically

Select this option to prevent devices from automatically syncing with this iTunes library when a device is connected. To sync a device, click the Sync button when the device is connected.

Delete Backup

Click this button to delete the selected backup. All backed up files are deleted and can’t be recovered.

Look for remote speakers connected with AirPlay

Play your iTunes library through external speakers using AirPlay or an AirPlay-enabled device.

Allow iTunes control from remote speakers

Control iTunes with a third-party remote connected to AirPort Express.

Look for iPod touch, iPhone, and iPad Remotes

Use the Remote app, available from the App Store, to control iTunes from your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad.

Forget All Remotes

Click to disconnect every iPod touch, iPhone, and iPad paired with this iTunes library via the Remote app.

See also
Back up your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad
Prevent unprompted syncing of your iPod, iPhone, or iPad
itns27563.name: iTunes Devices preferences
itns27563.summary: How to use the Devices preferences pane

itns27614.content:
You can choose settings for individual podcasts, and you can choose default settings that apply to any podcast without its own settings.

To choose settings for individual podcasts, deselect Use Default Settings and then choose your settings.

Menu

Settings

Check for new episodes

iTunes can automatically check for new episodes hourly, daily, or weekly. If you choose Manually, click Refresh at the bottom of the list of podcasts to check for new episodes.

Settings for

Choose the podcast you want these settings to apply to. If you want these settings to apply to all podcasts without their own settings, choose Podcast Defaults.

When new episodes are available

You can choose to automatically download all episodes or only the most recent episode. If you don’t want any episodes to download automatically, choose “Do nothing.”

This menu isn’t available if Use Default Settings is selected.

Episodes to keep

  • If you want to delete episodes manually, choose “All episodes.”

  • To keep each episode until you watch it and then automatically delete it, choose “All unplayed episodes.”

  • To automatically delete all older episodes, choose “Most recent episode” or “Last 2-10 episodes.”

This menu isn’t available if Use Default Settings is selected.

See also
Download and subscribe to podcasts
itns27614.name: Choose podcast settings
itns27614.summary: You can choose settings for individual podcasts, and you can choose default settings that apply to any podcast without its own settings.

itns27620.content:
This information is useful for finding and sorting items in your iTunes library. You can easily change this information to suit your preferences.

Item

Description

Artist

The group or person who recorded the CD

Composer

The songwriter or songwriters

Album

The CD title

Disc Number

This CD’s number, out of the total number of discs in this album

Genre

The music style (folk, rock, and so on)

Year

The year the album was released

Compilation CD

For an album with songs by multiple artists, such as a movie soundtrack. To group such albums together (rather than list each song with its particular artist), choose iTunes > Preferences, click Advanced, and select “Group compilations when browsing.”

Gapless Album

Select if you want this album to play without fading between songs or tracks, even when Crossfade Songs is selected in Playback preferences.

See also
Edit song and CD information
itns27620.name: CD info
itns27620.summary: Information iTunes can display when you insert a CD

itns29195.content:
Menu

Settings

Check for new episodes

iTunes can automatically check for new episodes hourly, daily, or weekly. If you choose Manually, click Refresh at the bottom of your iTunes U directory to check for new episodes.

When new episodes are available

You can set iTunes to download all available episodes or the most recent episode, or to do nothing.

Episodes to keep

If you want to delete episodes manually, choose “All episodes.” To keep each episode until you watch it and then automatically delete it, choose “All unplayed episodes.” To automatically delete all older episodes, choose “Most recent episode” or “Last 2-10 episodes.”
itns29195.name: iTunes U Settings
itns29195.summary: You can set how often iTunes checks for updates to the iTunes U media you subscribe to.

itns2938.name: Search your library or a playlist

itns2945.name: Delete songs, playlists, or other items

itns2954.name: If song titles don’t appear correctly

itns2964.name: Add items to your library without copying them to your iTunes folder

itns2965.content:
When you import songs into iTunes from CDs, the default encoding format is AAC (Advanced Audio Coding).

You can change the encoding format and other settings that iTunes uses to import songs. Your choices affect the audio quality and size of the song file (the higher the quality, the larger the file size). Songs you import into iTunes are stored on your computer’s hard disk.

You can use custom settings for greater control over the quality and size of imported files.

iTunes supports HE-ACC files (also called MPEG-4 AAC files). If you use Mac OS X v10.6.8 or earlier, HE-AAC encoding is available only if you have QuickTime 7.6.4 or later installed.

To choose import options:

  1. Choose iTunes > Preferences, click General, and click Import Settings.

  2. Choose an encoder from the Import Using pop-up menu.

    • You can listen to songs encoded in AAC or Apple Lossless formats in iTunes, on iPhone and iPad, and on iPod models that come with a dock connector. If you plan to listen to your music using a different program or MP3 player, choose MP3 Encoder.

    • If you want to burn high-quality audio CDs with the songs you’re importing without losing quality, choose Apple Lossless or AIFF. (Keep in mind that songs imported using this format use much more disc space.)

    • If you’ll be playing your songs on a computer that does not have MP3 software, choose WAV.

  3. Choose a bit rate from the Setting pop-up menu (not available with Apple Lossless Encoder). In most cases, the default selection works well.

  4. If you chose MP3 Encoder, choose one of the following from the Setting pop-up menu:

    • Good Quality: Choose to fit more songs on a portable MP3 player with limited storage capacity.

    • High Quality: Choose if you play music in a noisy environment. This setting creates files that are about 1 MB in size per minute of music.

    • Higher Quality: Choose if you plan to create your own audio CDs or listen to your music with high-quality stereo speakers.

    • Custom: Choose for greater control over the file size and sound quality.

To use custom settings with MP3 encoding:

  1. Choose iTunes > Preferences, click General, and click Import Settings.

  2. Choose MP3 Encoder from the Import Using pop-up menu.

  3. Choose Custom from the Setting pop-up menu.

  4. Choose settings from the following menus:

    • Stereo Bit Rate

    • Variable Bit Rate Encoding (VBR)

    • Sample Rate

    • Channels

    • Stereo Mode

    These settings are explained below in “What you can adjust using the encoding settings menus.”

  5. To have iTunes analyze your encoding settings and music source, select Smart Encoding Adjustments.

  6. Select or deselect Filter Frequencies Below 10 Hz.

    Filtering inaudible frequencies results in smaller, more efficient files without perceptible loss of quality.

To use custom settings with AIFF or WAV encoding:

  1. Choose iTunes > Preferences, click General, and click Import Settings.

  2. Choose AIFF Encoder or WAV Encoder from the Import Using pop-up menu.

  3. Choose Custom from the Setting pop-up menu.

  4. Choose settings in the Sample Rate, Sample Size, and Channels menus.

    These settings are explained below in “What you can adjust using the encoding settings menus.”

To use custom settings with AAC encoding:

  1. Choose iTunes > Preferences, click General, and click Import Settings.

  2. Choose AAC Encoder from the Import Using pop-up menu.

  3. Choose Custom from the Setting pop-up menu.

  4. Choose settings from the Stereo Bit Rate, Sample Rate, and Channels menus.

    These settings are explained below in “What you can adjust using the encoding settings menus.”

What you can adjust using the encoding settings menus:

  • The encoding settings are available only if you choose Custom from the Setting pop-up menu. Here’s a brief explanation of the music properties you can change:

    • Stereo Bit Rate: The higher the Mono or Stereo kilobits per second (kbps), the higher the audio quality and the larger the file size. The most common bit rate for stereo MP3 files is between 128 kbps and 192 kbps. Lower bit rates are more appropriate for sound files containing voice recordings (as opposed to music).

    • Variable Bit Rate Encoding (VBR): This setting varies the number of bits used to store the music depending on the complexity of the music. This can help keep file size to a minimum.

    • Sample Rate: The number of times per second that the music waveforms are captured digitally. The higher the sample rate, the higher the quality and the larger the file size. Don’t choose a sample rate higher than the rate used originally to store the music or you’ll waste space. CD quality, for example, is 44.100 kHz, so choosing a higher rate when you’re encoding from a CD is unnecessary. In general, the best choice is Auto, which uses the same rate as the original music.

    • Sample Size: The number of bits used to store each sample taken as the music is encoded. The higher the sample size, the better the quality and the larger the file size.

    • Channels: If you don’t have stereo speakers or if your audio files are monaural (mono files are about half the size of stereo files), choose Mono. If you’ll be listening through headphones or a stereo system, choose Stereo or Auto. Auto converts monaural tracks into mono files and stereo tracks into stereo files.

    • Stereo Mode: In Normal mode, your MP3 files contain one track for the right stereo channel and one track for the left. In many cases, the two channels contain related information. In Joint Stereo mode, one channel carries the information that’s identical on both channels, and the other channel carries the unique information. At bit rates of 160 kbps and below, this can improve the sound quality of your converted audio.

See also
Save a copy of a song in a new file format
itns2965.name: Choose import settings
itns2965.summary: You can change the settings that iTunes uses when importing files into your library for greater control over file size or quality.

Apple TV Setup Guide

itns2b904556.summary: Complete information about using Apple TV is available in the Setup Guide.

itns3001.content:
iTunes can create playlists of certain types of music, songs with certain ratings, or songs that match other rules you specify. iTunes can update these playlists automatically.

For example, you could create a Smart Playlist that’s no more than 5 gigabytes (GB) in size and includes your most highly rated jazz songs. Or you could create a Smart Playlist of songs by a particular artist. When you import a new CD from that artist, the songs are added automatically to the Smart Playlist.

If you want to create more complex rules—for example, with some criteria matching all rules and others matching any—you can create sets of rules, or “nested” rules. You can have up to five levels of nesting.

A Smart Playlist has this icon next to it. iTunes comes with several Smart Playlists already set up, including My Top Rated, Recently Added, and Top 25 Most Played.

To create a Smart Playlist:

  1. Choose File > New Smart Playlist.

  2. Specify your rules.

    To add another set of rules, hold down the Option key and click the Nest button . (When you hold down the Option key, the Add button changes to the Nest button.)

To change a Smart Playlist, select it and choose File > Edit Smart Playlist.

To remove a Smart Playlist, select it in a list on the left side of the iTunes window and press the Delete key.
itns3001.name: Create a Smart Playlist
itns3001.summary: You can have iTunes add any songs that meet specific criteria to a playlist by creating a Smart Playlist.

itns3008.name: Set up an Apple ID account for use in the iTunes Store

itns3009.name: Sign in or out of the iTunes Store

itns3010.content:
To play many purchases from the iTunes Store, you must authorize your computer using your Apple ID and password. (Authorization helps protect the copyrights of the purchased items.)

You can have up to five authorized computers (Macintosh, Windows, or both) at a time. To play a purchased item on a sixth computer, you need to deauthorize another one. An iPod, iPhone, iPad, or Apple TV doesn’t count as a computer.

You can authorize or deauthorize a computer at any time. Be sure to deauthorize a computer before you sell it or give it away.

Here are ways to authorize or deauthorize a computer:

  • To authorize a computer to play iTunes Store purchases, choose Store > Authorize Computer.

  • To deauthorize a computer, choose Store > Deauthorize Computer.

  • To deauthorize a computer to play spoken programs purchased from the Audible website, choose Advanced > Deauthorize Audible Account.

  • If you forgot to deauthorize a computer you no longer own, and you have five authorized computers, you can deauthorize all your authorized computers at once. You can use this method once a year.

    Choose Store > View My Account, and click Deauthorize All. If you don’t see this option, it’s because you don’t have five authorized computers.

If you have trouble deauthorizing a computer, visit the iTunes Store Authorization FAQ website.

See also
Usage rights for iTunes Store purchases
Find iTunes files
itns3010.name: Authorize a computer to play iTunes Store purchases
itns3010.summary: You can authorize up to five computers at a time to play iTunes Store purchases.

itns3012.name: Buy items from the iTunes Store

itns3014.name: Change your Apple ID account information

itns3027.name: Add artwork to songs and other items

itns3090.content:
iTunes can create a playlist of random songs from your library or a playlist. An iTunes DJ playlist continually updates itself (it’s a “live mix”), and you can edit it at any time.

While you’re playing an iTunes DJ mix, you can use the Remote app on your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad to request songs. You can also allow guests to request songs to play and to vote on songs. Voting affects when and whether a song plays.

You can download the Remote app from the iTunes Store.

To create an iTunes DJ live mix:

  1. Below Playlists, click iTunes DJ .

    If you’re selecting iTunes DJ for the first time, click Continue.

  2. Do any of the following:

    • To select a specific playlist (instead of your library) for the live mix, choose an option from the Source pop-up menu at the bottom of the iTunes window.

    • To change the number of played or upcoming songs you want to see in the playlist, click Settings.

    • To change the order or add new songs, drag them.

    • To delete a song, select it and press Delete.

To hide the iTunes DJ playlist:

  1. Choose iTunes > Preferences, and click General.

  2. Deselect iTunes DJ in the General pane.

To allow guests to request and vote on songs:

  1. On the left side of the iTunes window, click iTunes DJ (below Playlists).

  2. Click Settings (at the bottom of the window).

  3. In the iTunes DJ Settings window, select “Allow guests to request songs with Remote for iPhone and iPod touch.”

  4. Do any of the following:

    • To limit your guests’ choices, select “Restrict requests to source” and choose a source from the pop-up menu.

    • To allow guests to vote on songs, select Enable Voting.

    • To require guests to enter a password before they can make a request or vote, select “Require password” and type the password.

    • To customize the message guests see when they join, type in the Welcome Message area.

To request songs using Remote:

  1. On your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad, tap Settings and choose the host’s Wi-Fi network.

  2. Tap Remote to open the Remote app.

  3. Tap the iTunes DJ name to join the party. If the host has required a password, type it.

  4. To request a song, tap “Request a Song” and then tap the song.

  5. To vote on a song in the iTunes DJ mix, tap it and then tap Like It or Dislike It.

See also
Play, shuffle, or repeat songs
itns3090.name: Create a mix using iTunes DJ

itns32504.content:
The first time you connect your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad to your computer, iTunes asks for your permission to collect and analyze diagnostic and usage information from your device.

Apple uses the information to improve the quality and performance of its products and services. The information may include details about hardware and operating system specifications, performance statistics, and data about how you use your device and apps.

Diagnostic and usage information is collected only with your explicit consent, and is submitted anonymously to Apple. None of the collected information identifies you personally. Personal data is either not logged at all, or is removed from any reports before they’re sent to Apple.

To select reporting options when you set up your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad:

  1. Connect your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad to your computer and follow the onscreen instructions to set up your device.

    During setup, a message appears, asking your permission to send diagnostic and usage information about your device to Apple.

  2. Do one of the following:

    • To allow iTunes to send information automatically, select “Do not ask me again,” and then click Agree.

    • If you want iTunes to ask for your permission each time it sends information to Apple, deselect “Do not ask me again,” and then click Agree.

    • If you don’t want your device information sent to Apple, select “Do not ask me again,” and then click Disagree.

To change your device’s reporting options:

  1. Connect your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad to your computer.

  2. In iTunes, hold down the Control key on your keyboard while you click your device (below Devices).

  3. Choose Reset Warnings from the menu that appears.

    The next time iTunes asks you for permission to send information, follow step 2 in the above section to set your reporting options.

Reports are submitted to Apple using your Internet connection. Your computer and device keep the information for one month after a report is generated, and then delete the information.

For more information, see Apple Customer Privacy Policy
itns32504.name: Sending diagnostic and usage information about your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad to Apple

itns34267c28.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

Device backups

Displays a list of backups of devices that are synced with this computer. Encrypted backups are identified with a lock icon. Position the pointer over an item on the list to display the device’s serial number.

Delete Backup

Click this button to delete the selected backup. All backed up files are deleted and can’t be recovered.

Prevent iPods, iPhones, and iPads from syncing automatically

Select this option to prevent devices from automatically syncing with this iTunes library when a device is connected. To sync a device, click the Sync button when the device is connected.

Allow iTunes control from remote speakers

Control iTunes with a third-party remote connected to AirPort Express.

Forget All Remotes

Click to disconnect every iPod touch, iPhone, and iPad paired with this iTunes library via the Remote app.

See also
Back up your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad
Prevent unprompted syncing of your iPod, iPhone, or iPad
itns34267c28.name: iTunes Devices preferences
itns34267c28.summary: How to use the Devices preferences pane

itns34267f4e.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

Automatic downloads

When you make purchases from the iTunes Store on your iPod touch, iPhone, or iPad, or on another computer, the purchased items can be automatically downloaded to this computer.

"When downloading High Definition videos, prefer” menu

When you purchase or rent high-definition videos from the iTunes Store, you can choose to have them downloaded in 720p or 1080p quality (if both formats are available). 1080p-quality videos can be synced only to devices that support this format.

Always check for available downloads

iTunes displays the number of items you previously purchased from the iTunes Store but didn’t download.

Automatically download pre-orders when available

Automatically download items you pay for in advance, such as new episodes of a TV show you purchased with a Season Pass, as they become available.

See also
iTunes Store overview
Buy items from the iTunes Store
Download previous purchases from the iTunes Store
Verify iTunes Store purchases
Set up an Apple ID account for use in the iTunes Store
Pre-order items from the iTunes Store
itns34267f4e.name: iTunes Store preferences
itns34267f4e.summary: How to use the iTunes Store preferences pane

itns34268017.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

Share my library on my local network

Allow up to five other computers on your local network to display and play items from your library. You can share your entire library or select specific playlists to share.

If you select “Require password,” others can see your library but they can’t play anything without the password you specify.

Home Sharing computers and devices update play counts

Play counts for items in your iTunes library are updated when the items are played on other computers in your Home Sharing network, or on your iPod, iPhone, or iPad.

See also
Share your iTunes library
itns34268017.name: iTunes Sharing preferences
itns34268017.summary: How to use the iTunes Sharing preferences pane

itns342680d0.content:
iTunes lets you restrict or prevent access to the iTunes Store, shared libraries, and certain types of content. For computers with multiple user accounts, you can set different controls for specific users, but still allow unrestricted access from administrator accounts.

Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

“Disable” checkboxes

Prevent access to certain parts of iTunes. To prevent access to the iTunes Store, but still allow access to educational content, select both “iTunes Store” and “Allow access to iTunes U.”

“Ratings for” menu

Choose the rating system for the country you’re in.

Show content ratings in library

Display or hide Explicit ratings for items in your iTunes library.

Content Restrictions

Restrict access to items in the iTunes Store by ratings and type of content. Password is required for previews and purchases of restricted items.

Click the lock to prevent further changes

Prevent unwanted changes to parental controls by requiring an administrator’s password to unlock.

See also
Restrict access to explicit content in the iTunes Store
About parental advisory labels
itns342680d0.name: iTunes Parental Control preferences
itns342680d0.summary: How to use the Parental preferences pane

itns34268177.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

iTunes Media folder location

To change where songs and other files you import into iTunes are located, click Change.

To change back to the original location for files (Home/Music/iTunes), click Reset.

Keep iTunes Media folder organized

Automatically put imported music into folders for album and artist.

Copy files to iTunes Media folder when adding to library

Copy an item to the iTunes Media folder when you drag the item to the iTunes window or choose File > “Add to Library.”

If you want items to appear in iTunes but also remain in their original location, deselect this checkbox. For example, you can keep music imported from CDs on your computer’s hard disk, and save your video files on an external hard disk.

Pressing the Option key while dragging temporarily reverses the current checkbox setting.

Reset all dialog warnings

If you selected “Do not show this message again” in one or more dialogs (small windows with messages in them), clicking Reset makes the messages appear again, as if you’d just opened iTunes for the first time.

Reset iTunes Store cache

iTunes saves the store pages you visit on your computer in a temporary location called the “cache.” If you return later, iTunes can retrieve the page from the cache faster than getting it from the Internet.

If the content on a page seems outdated, you may want to reset the cache to make iTunes retrieve the latest version of the page. If you think a page is not opening properly, resetting the cache may help.

Keep Mini Player on top of all other windows

Keep the Mini Player (the iTunes window after you click the green zoom button) in front of all open windows, even while you use applications other than iTunes.

Keep movie window on top of all other windows

When playing video in a separate window, keep the movie window in front of all open windows, even while you use applications other than iTunes.

See also
iTunes Store overview
Find iTunes files
Add items to your library without copying them to your iTunes folder
Listen to Internet radio
Customize the iTunes window
Turn on visual effects
itns34268177.name: iTunes Advanced preferences
itns34268177.summary: How to use the iTunes Advanced preferences pane

itns3426820e.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

Library Name

You can rename your iTunes library. This is useful if you use more than one library. If you turn on iTunes library sharing, others see this name.

“Show” checkboxes

Display or hide items in the iTunes window.

Source Text

Change the text size for items listed on the left side of the iTunes window.

Show source icons

Display or hide the icons in the list on the left side of the iTunes window.

List Text

Change the text size for items in your library, when you use list view.

Show list checkboxes

Display or hide checkboxes when you use list view.

Grid View

Change the background for items in your library, when you use grid view.

When you insert a CD

Change what happens when you insert a CD in your computer’s CD drive.

Import Settings

Choose the file format and other settings for songs you import from CDs.

Automatically retrieve CD track names from Internet

Automatically display song and artist names when you insert an audio CD. (To retrieve track names, you must be connected to the Internet.)

Automatically download missing album artwork

Automatically add album artwork for music you import into iTunes from CDs or other sources. Artwork is already included with all music purchased from the iTunes Store.

Check for new software updates automatically

Display a message when a new version of iTunes is available.

See also
Use multiple iTunes libraries
Keyboard shortcuts
Customize the iTunes window
If you don’t see song information
Accessibility solutions for iTunes
itns3426820e.name: iTunes General preferences
itns3426820e.summary: How to use the iTunes General preferences pane

itns342682b6.content:
Changes you make to preferences take effect when you close the preferences window.

Preference

Explanation

Crossfade Songs

Fade songs in and out, with no silence between songs. Drag the slider to change the amount of time it takes for the current song to fade out at the end and the new song to fade in.

Sound Enhancer

Change the music’s sound quality during playback. Drag the slider to increase or decrease the Sound Enhancer’s effect.

Sound Check

Play all music and video at the same volume level.

Audio Language

Change the default playback language.

Subtitle Language

Change the language used for movie subtitles and closed captions.

Play videos using standard definition version

Always play non-HD video, even if a high-definition version is available. You might want to choose this if you have an older computer that can’t play HD video well.

Show closed captioning when available

Display a text transcript of dialog and voiceover while playing movies and TV shows.

See also
Play, shuffle, or repeat songs
Adjust the sound quality
Turn on visual effects
Use subtitles and alternative audio tracks

itns5f29db12.content:
You can share and edit playlists you publish to the iTunes Store directly from Ping.

When you create and publish your playlists in the iTunes Store, your playlists automatically appear in Ping, and your followers are notified on their Recent Activity page.

In addition, your Ping followers can:

  • Add songs to playlists, if you allow it.

  • Like a playlist by marking it “Like.”

  • Comment, rate, or review a playlist.

  • Post a playlist to their Recent Activity page.

To see all of your published playlists:

  1. In iTunes, click Ping (below Store).

  2. In iTunes Ping, click My Playlists.

To change or delete a published playlist:

  1. In iTunes, click Ping (below Store).

  2. In iTunes Ping, click My Playlists.

  3. Select the playlist you want to change or delete, and then click Edit.

  4. Do any of the following:

    • To change the playlist’s title and description, type any changes.

    • To let your followers add songs to your playlist after it’s published, select “Allow my followers to add songs.”

    • To add a song, click Add Songs, select a song, and then click Add. When you’re finished adding songs, click Done.

      • To find a song by album, artist, or song title use the Search field.

      • To hear a 30-second preview of the song before adding it, double-click the song’s title or click the Preview button for the song.

    • To remove a song, click “x” to the right of the Buy button for the song you want to remove.

    • To arrange your playlist, drag songs in the order you want.

    • To delete the playlist, click Delete this playlist.

  5. When you’re finished making changes, click Save.

To allow others to add songs to your playlists:

  • Select “Allow my followers to add songs” when you create or edit a playlist.
itns5f29db12.name: Share and edit playlists directly from Ping
itns5f29db12.summary: You can share and edit playlists you publish to the iTunes Store directly from Ping.

itns8e44d445.content:
When you become a member of iTunes Ping, you can follow your favorite artists and other music fans, and other people can follow you. You can also invite friends to iTunes Ping via email.

iTunes Ping recommends artists and people you may be interested in following. You can also search for artists and other members. When you follow an artist, you can see their recent activity in iTunes Ping, such as music they enjoy or an announcement about an upcoming release.

If you want to require your approval to be followed, see Create an iTunes Ping profile for instructions.

To search for people and artist profiles:

When you sign up for iTunes Ping, iTunes shows you your Recent Activity page to make it easy to start following people, and recommends artists and featured people. You can search for friends by name, or invite friends to iTunes Ping via email.

To search for friends by name:

  1. In iTunes Ping, click People.

  2. Type a name in the search field that appears on the page, and press Return.

    Your search results appear in a new page. You can view All, or you can view by Artists or People.

You can also find artists and people by clicking Featured Artists or Featured People.

To follow an artist or person:

  1. In iTunes Ping, search for the person or artist you want to follow.

  2. Click Follow. If the person requires approval to be followed, a request is sent.

To stop following an artist or person:

  1. In iTunes Ping, click People.

  2. Click the People I Follow tab to see a list of people you follow.

  3. Select the artist or person you want to remove from the list, and click Stop Following.

To stop a person from following you:

  1. In iTunes Ping, click People.

  2. Click the People Who Follow Me tab.

  3. Select the person you want to remove from the list, and click Remove.

To accept or ignore follow requests:

  1. In iTunes Ping, click the People tab.

  2. Click the Follow Requests tab to see a list of requests.

  3. Select a request, and choose Confirm or Ignore.

If you choose Confirm, a notification is sent back to the requestor. If you choose Ignore, no notification is sent.

To invite your friends to iTunes Ping via email:

  • In iTunes Ping, click People, click Invite, and follow the onscreen instructions.
itns8e44d445.name: Find and follow artists and people
itns8e44d445.summary: Find and follow your friends and favorite artists.

itns8e44d530.name: Connect to artists and people with iTunes Ping

itns8e44d6e4.content:
iTunes Ping makes it easy to follow your favorite artists and friends or connect with the world's most passionate music fans, and discover the music everyone is talking about, listening to, and downloading.

You can use iTunes Ping to read real-time updates from the people you follow, see photos and watch videos posted by your favorite artists, discover the music your friends are buying, and find out who's going to a concert near you.

You can also tell your followers about the music you like and recommend, have iTunes Ping notify them whenever you write a review, and comment on their updates.

When you publish a playlist in the iTunes Store, your Ping followers are notified, and you can share and edit it directly from Ping. You and your Ping followers can edit, like, comment on, or post each others’ playlists in Ping.

To use iTunes Ping, you need to create a free profile using an Apple ID.

Discover Music with Ping

Watch the movie (about 2 minutes)
itns8e44d6e4.name: iTunes Ping overview
itns8e44d6e4.summary: iTunes Ping makes it easy to follow your favorite artists and connect with other music fans.

itns8e44d7cf.content:
Before using iTunes Ping to follow artists and other music fans, you need to set up a free profile in iTunes Ping. Make sure you’re signed into the iTunes Store.

To create an iTunes Ping profile:

  1. In iTunes, click Ping (below Store).

  2. Click “Turn on iTunes Ping,” and enter your Apple ID information.

  3. Follow the onscreen instructions to accept terms and conditions, add your profile information, and set privacy settings.

    To require approval before someone can follow you, select “Require approval to follow me.”
itns8e44d7cf.name: Create an iTunes Ping profile
itns8e44d7cf.summary: To use iTunes Ping, you need to create a free profile in the iTunes Store.

itns8e44def4.content:
iTunes Ping lets you follow the activities that you or the artists or people you follow create in iTunes Ping or the iTunes Store.

For example, when you purchase an album or song in the iTunes Store, your purchase activity appears to your followers in iTunes Ping. Or if your favorite artist posts a comment or has a concert your friends are going to, you can find out all about it in iTunes Ping as well.

To view and manage activities:

  • In iTunes Ping, click Recent Activity to see a list of all recent activities. For each activity, you can do any of the following:

    • Flag an item as inappropriate.

    • Like an item.

    • Comment on an item.

    • Post an item.

To follow concerts, find tickets, and let friends know you’re going:

  • On the Recent Activity page, click Concerts. A list of concerts and tour information for the artists you follow appears.

    • To find tickets, click Find Tickets.

    • To let your followers know you’re going to the concert, click I’m Going.

To notify your followers that you like a song or album:

  • Find the song or album you want to notify your followers about in either the iTunes Store or your iTunes library.

    • For items in the iTunes Store, click the Like button for the item.

    • For items in your iTunes library, click the link next to the item, and then choose Like from the pop-up menu.

    Your iTunes Ping followers will see that you like the song or album in their Recent Activity feed.

To post a song or album to iTunes Ping:

  1. Find the song or album you want to notify your followers about in either the iTunes Store or your iTunes library.

    • For items in the iTunes Store, click the Post button for the item.

    • For items in your iTunes library, click the link next to the item, and then choose Post from the pop-up menu.

  2. Type any comments you want to appear in the post, and click Submit.

    Your iTunes Ping followers will see your post in their Recent Activity feed.

To review an album:

  1. In iTunes, click iTunes Store (below Store).

  2. Go to the album page for the album you want to review.

  3. Click “Write a Review” (below Customer Reviews).

  4. Type the title of the album, and write your review.

  5. Click Submit.

    Your review is submitted to the iTunes Store, and your followers will see your review, and a link to it on the album page, in their Recent Activity feed.
itns8e44def4.name: View and manage iTunes Ping activities
itns8e44def4.summary: Learn about the Recent Activity feed in iTunes Ping.

itnsb27dda8c.content:
If your computer’s firewall settings prevent you from using iTunes features such as music sharing, AirTunes, and Apple TV, you can change the settings to allow you to use these features.

To change your computer’s firewall settings:

  1. Open System Preferences, click Security, and then click Firewall.

  2. Click Advanced.

  3. Do one of the following:

    • If “Block all incoming connections” is selected, deselect it.

    • If iTunes is included in the list of applications, choose “Allow incoming connections.”

  4. Click OK.

If you're connected to the Internet, and the content still doesn’t appear, try again later.
itnsf987d673.name: The selected topic is currently unavailable
